reasoning: The critique targets an explicit simplifying assumption in §2: that WAM-convergence (widespread, accurate, motivating convergence on the good de dicto) is sufficient for reaching a mostly-great future. That assumption is important for how the essay allocates attention (it lets it analyze convergence rather than implementation/control), but it is not the essay’s main conclusion (the essay ends up pessimistic about WAM and shifts to partial convergence + trade and to blockers), so centrality is moderate rather than maximal. The critique’s core point is substantively plausible: sincere convergence on correct values does not by itself guarantee robust translation into large-scale outcomes in adversarial, AI-mediated environments; a further premise about governance/technical control is doing work. However, the essay partially insulates itself via the vague “reasonably good conditions” and its “blockers” discussion (including cases where humanity ‘will not choose its future at all’), so the critique does not fully overturn the targeted move; it mainly demands an explicit, separately-analyzed execution premise. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight, and the counterexample is reasonable rather than speculative handwaving.
title: Moral convergence alone cannot ensure good outcomes without reliable implementation mechanisms
